analyzeResult.content:
editorial
The Role of the Addictive Process as a Key Step in Causation of All Tobacco-Related Diseases
Two circumstances-the fact that cigarette smoking is the single larges preventable cause of disease and death in the country' and the rapid development of a new body of knowl- edge concerning the addictive process-combine to provide an unparalleled opportunity for American medicine to fulfill its pri- mary responsibility-"the reduction of suffering and death."
The magnificent neuroadaptability of our species at times becomes dangerous and expensive. We can, unfortunately, come to accept familiar and well-known situations as givens, a part of the landscape. As a result of this adaptability, we frequently overlook important factors that have become so familiar they have lost their saliency. Applied to cigarette smoking, we need to see relative burdens of mortality and morbidity more clearly again, as for the first time. The 350,000 excess deaths per year attributable to cigarette smoking constitute more than all other drug and alcohol abuse deaths combined, seven times more than all automobile fatalities per year, more than a hundred times all recorded deaths caused by the acquired immunodeficiency syndrome, and more than all American military fatalities in World War I, World War II, and Vietnam put together.“
We can conservatively estimate that /nore than 60% of these yearly deaths do not result from ignorance or from a freely chosen risk of adult smokers but instead represent persons who became addicted to nicotine as adolescents before the age of legal consent." It has now been conclusively demonstrated that nicotine is a powerfully addictive drug." The consequent syndrome-tobacco-dependence disorder-is newly added to the domestic and international classification of disease. Its neurophysiology and neurochemistry are being elucidated at a rapid pace. It is important to recognize that it is this addictive process that keeps the body tissues exposed to carcinogens and the biochemical contributors to cardiovascular disease for many years.
The essential diagnostic criterion of DSM-III 305.1 -- Tobacco Dependence Disorder-is defined as the inability to discontinue smoking despite awareness of medical conse- quence. Ninety percent of regular smokers have tried to quit, and most smokers began smoking and became dependent while still in their teens." When measured by the percentage of users who lose control of their substance intake, nicotine is six to eight times more addictive than alcohol.
It is equally important to recognize that, with adequate motivation and appropriate therapeutic approaches, dramatic levels of success can be achieved in addictive disorders. For
example, complete environmental change and elimination of drug-associated stimuli enabled more than 70% of American servicemen addicted to heroin in Vietnam to overcome that addiction on their return to the United States.' In some respects, the nicotine addict-the regular smoker who wishes to quit but can't-has a more difficult job given the constant repetition of smoking stimuli he is exposed to. However, we know that (1) more than 30 million regular smokers have been able to stop smoking in the past 20 years and (2) that when physicians systematically, consistently, but in non-guilt-produc- ing fashion place a continuing high priority on smoking cessation, the results can be surprisingly potent."""
History makes clear that legal prohibition of a behavior as widespread as cigarette smoking is not practical. However, it does appear that our society should seek some appropriate way to inhibit the present degree of freedom to "push" its most prevalent drug of abuse-nicotine. Until then, we physicians must become more familiar with our most deadly addictive drug (nicotine) and much more involved in appropriate prevention and treatment efforts. More than 200,000 lives per year can be saved if we achieve the same level of success in dealing with nicotine that was reached by returning Vietnam heroin addicts."
WILLIAM POLLIN, MD National Institute on Drug Abuse Rockville, Md
1. A Report of the Surgeon General: Chronic Obstructive Lang Disease, Dept of Health and Human Services publication 84-50205. Office of the Assistant Secretary for Health, 1984.
2. Prywes M: A physician's destiny. Albert Einstein College of Medicine commencement address, Bronx, NY, July 6, 1979.
3. A Report of the Surgeon General: Smoking and Health, Dept of Health and Human Services publication 79-50066. Office of the Assistant Secretary for Health, 1979,
4. Update: Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS)-United States. MMIFR 1984:39:337-339.
5. Fatal Accident Reporting System 1982: An Overview of U.S. Trafic Facility Accidents and Fatal Data Collected in FARS, Dept of Transportation publication (HS) 806566. National Highway Traffic Safety Association, May 1984.
6. Borvin GJ: Prevention of Adolescent Substance Abuse Through the Develop- ment of Personal and Social Consegnener, Dept of Health and Human Services publication (ADM) 83-1280. Rockville, Md, National Institute on Drug Abuse, 1984.
7. Russell MAH: Tobacco smoking and nicotine dependence, In Gibbins RJ. Isreal Y, Kalant il, et al (eds): Research Advances in Alcohol and Drag Problems. New York, John Wiley & Sons Inc, 1976,
8. Pollin W. Why People Smoke Cigarettes. Depe of Health and Human Services publication (NIDA) 83-50195. Rockville, Md, National Institute on Drug Abuse, 1984.
9. Robbins LN: A Fallwrap of Vietnam Drug Users, Special Action Ofice monograph 1. series A. Washington, DC, Executive Office of the President. 1974.
10. The Vietnam Drag User Retarms, Special Action Ofice monograph 2. series A. Washington, DC., Government Printing Office, 197.4.
11. Russell MAH, Wilson C. Taylor C. et al: Effects of general practitioners' advice against smoking. Br Med / 1979,2.231-235.
Address editorial communications to the Editor, 636 N Dearborn St, Chicago, IL 60610.
2874 JAMA, Nov 23/30, 1984-Vol 252, No. 20
Editorial
TIMN 311326 :selected:

lines.content: editorial
The Role of the Addictive Process
as a Key Step in Causation of All
Tobacco-Related Diseases
Two circumstances-the fact that cigarette smoking is the
single larges preventable cause of disease and death in the
country' and the rapid development of a new body of knowl-
edge concerning the addictive process-combine to provide an
unparalleled opportunity for American medicine to fulfill its pri-
mary responsibility-"the reduction of suffering and death."
The magnificent neuroadaptability of our species at times
becomes dangerous and expensive. We can, unfortunately,
come to accept familiar and well-known situations as givens, a
part of the landscape. As a result of this adaptability, we
frequently overlook important factors that have become so
familiar they have lost their saliency. Applied to cigarette
smoking, we need to see relative burdens of mortality and
morbidity more clearly again, as for the first time. The 350,000
excess deaths per year attributable to cigarette smoking
constitute more than all other drug and alcohol abuse deaths
combined, seven times more than all automobile fatalities per
year, more than a hundred times all recorded deaths caused by
the acquired immunodeficiency syndrome, and more than all
American military fatalities in World War I, World War II, and
Vietnam put together.“
We can conservatively estimate that /nore than 60% of these
yearly deaths do not result from ignorance or from a freely
chosen risk of adult smokers but instead represent persons who
became addicted to nicotine as adolescents before the age of
legal consent." It has now been conclusively demonstrated that
nicotine is a powerfully addictive drug." The consequent
syndrome-tobacco-dependence disorder-is newly added to
the domestic and international classification of disease. Its
neurophysiology and neurochemistry are being elucidated at a
rapid pace. It is important to recognize that it is this addictive
process that keeps the body tissues exposed to carcinogens and
the biochemical contributors to cardiovascular disease for
many years.
The essential diagnostic criterion of DSM-III 305.1 --
Tobacco Dependence Disorder-is defined as the inability to
discontinue smoking despite awareness of medical conse-
quence. Ninety percent of regular smokers have tried to quit,
and most smokers began smoking and became dependent
while still in their teens." When measured by the percentage of
users who lose control of their substance intake, nicotine is six
to eight times more addictive than alcohol.
It is equally important to recognize that, with adequate
motivation and appropriate therapeutic approaches, dramatic
levels of success can be achieved in addictive disorders. For
example, complete environmental change and elimination of
drug-associated stimuli enabled more than 70% of American
servicemen addicted to heroin in Vietnam to overcome that
addiction on their return to the United States.' In some
respects, the nicotine addict-the regular smoker who wishes to
quit but can't-has a more difficult job given the constant
repetition of smoking stimuli he is exposed to. However, we
know that (1) more than 30 million regular smokers have been
able to stop smoking in the past 20 years and (2) that when
physicians systematically, consistently, but in non-guilt-produc-
ing fashion place a continuing high priority on smoking
cessation, the results can be surprisingly potent."""
History makes clear that legal prohibition of a behavior as
widespread as cigarette smoking is not practical. However, it
does appear that our society should seek some appropriate way
to inhibit the present degree of freedom to "push" its most
prevalent drug of abuse-nicotine. Until then, we physicians
must become more familiar with our most deadly addictive
drug (nicotine) and much more involved in appropriate
prevention and treatment efforts. More than 200,000 lives per
year can be saved if we achieve the same level of success in
dealing with nicotine that was reached by returning Vietnam
heroin addicts."
WILLIAM POLLIN, MD
National Institute on Drug Abuse
Rockville, Md

Health and Human Services publication 84-50205. Office of the Assistant
Secretary for Health, 1984.
2. Prywes M: A physician's destiny. Albert Einstein College of Medicine

6. Borvin GJ: Prevention of Adolescent Substance Abuse Through the Develop-
ment of Personal and Social Consegnener, Dept of Health and Human Services
publication (ADM) 83-1280. Rockville, Md, National Institute on Drug Abuse,
7. Russell MAH: Tobacco smoking and nicotine dependence, In Gibbins RJ.
Isreal Y, Kalant il, et al (eds): Research Advances in Alcohol and Drag Problems.
New York, John Wiley & Sons Inc, 1976,
8. Pollin W. Why People Smoke Cigarettes. Depe of Health and Human
Services publication (NIDA) 83-50195. Rockville, Md, National Institute on
Drug Abuse, 1984.
9. Robbins LN: A Fallwrap of Vietnam Drug Users, Special Action Ofice

paragraphs.content: editorial
The Role of the Addictive Process as a Key Step in Causation of All Tobacco-Related Diseases

Two circumstances-the fact that cigarette smoking is the single larges preventable cause of disease and death in the country' and the rapid development of a new body of knowl- edge concerning the addictive process-combine to provide an unparalleled opportunity for American medicine to fulfill its pri- mary responsibility-"the reduction of suffering and death."

The magnificent neuroadaptability of our species at times becomes dangerous and expensive. We can, unfortunately, come to accept familiar and well-known situations as givens, a part of the landscape. As a result of this adaptability, we frequently overlook important factors that have become so familiar they have lost their saliency. Applied to cigarette smoking, we need to see relative burdens of mortality and morbidity more clearly again, as for the first time. The 350,000 excess deaths per year attributable to cigarette smoking constitute more than all other drug and alcohol abuse deaths combined, seven times more than all automobile fatalities per year, more than a hundred times all recorded deaths caused by the acquired immunodeficiency syndrome, and more than all American military fatalities in World War I, World War II, and Vietnam put together.“

We can conservatively estimate that /nore than 60% of these yearly deaths do not result from ignorance or from a freely chosen risk of adult smokers but instead represent persons who became addicted to nicotine as adolescents before the age of legal consent." It has now been conclusively demonstrated that nicotine is a powerfully addictive drug." The consequent syndrome-tobacco-dependence disorder-is newly added to the domestic and international classification of disease. Its neurophysiology and neurochemistry are being elucidated at a rapid pace. It is important to recognize that it is this addictive process that keeps the body tissues exposed to carcinogens and the biochemical contributors to cardiovascular disease for many years.

The essential diagnostic criterion of DSM-III 305.1 -- Tobacco Dependence Disorder-is defined as the inability to discontinue smoking despite awareness of medical conse- quence. Ninety percent of regular smokers have tried to quit, and most smokers began smoking and became dependent while still in their teens." When measured by the percentage of users who lose control of their substance intake, nicotine is six to eight times more addictive than alcohol.
It is equally important to recognize that, with adequate motivation and appropriate therapeutic approaches, dramatic levels of success can be achieved in addictive disorders. For

example, complete environmental change and elimination of drug-associated stimuli enabled more than 70% of American servicemen addicted to heroin in Vietnam to overcome that addiction on their return to the United States.' In some respects, the nicotine addict-the regular smoker who wishes to quit but can't-has a more difficult job given the constant repetition of smoking stimuli he is exposed to. Until then, we physicians must become more familiar with our most deadly addictive drug (nicotine) and much more involved in appropriate prevention and treatment efforts. More than 200,000 lives per year can be saved if we achieve the same level of success in dealing with nicotine that was reached by returning Vietnam heroin addicts."
WILLIAM POLLIN, MD National Institute on Drug Abuse Rockville, Md
